attributes.title: Hasbro: Earnings Growth Is Impressive, But Can Free Cash Flow Rise In Tandem?
summary: Hasbro has shown growth in free cash flow, but this has been quite volatile.
Assuming 15 percent free cash flow growth per year, I see a target price of $116 for the company.
However, with recent sales growth being increasingly driven by cost savings, this is positive news for Hasbro.

attributes.content:
MY CURRENT RATING: HOLD

On the basis of a discounted free cash flow analysis, Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) is shown to have a target price ranging from $74 assuming 5 percent free cash flow growth per annum to $116 assuming 15 percent free cash flow growth per annum.

Overall, while growth in free cash flow has been erratic at times for this company, overall growth has been positive, showing an average of 15 percent in the past five years. However, we see that FCF growth has shown significantly less consistency than that of EPS (diluted) growth:

Overall, from the beginning of 2012 Hasbro has seen an average of 15 percent growth in free cash flow per year in spite of large quarterly fluctuations. On this basis, a discounted cash flow model using a 5 percent discount rate, along with three growth scenarios of 5, 10, and 15 percent in free cash flow yields the terminal values below.

Discounted Cash Flow Analysis

A terminal P/FCF ratio is assumed at the current value of 23.04, which in my view represents a fair long-run average of overall free cash flow per share, discounting periods of large volatility:

At the current price of $80.50 at the time of writing, we see that investors should be expecting a minimum of 10 percent growth in free cash flow on a mean annual basis for significant value to be yielded from the stock.

In spite of a short-term headwind for the company given that Universal Studios will now hand licensing rights for the Jurassic Park franchise to rival Mattel (NASDAQ:MAT), I still see significant growth in free cash flow as being achievable for Hasbro.
